title: Before 1 January 2018, will Fitch, Moody's, or S&P cut the State of Illinois’ credit rating to junk status?
preds: Monitoring current political adherence to liberal stands for spending vs saving in II
There isn't enough financial news pending for them to make that decision before year's end.  An unemployment jump may do it, but that would have a significant lead time.
Reaffirming my forecast, but considering new information.
Probably not this year, but there is a downgrade in the future:
near as I can tell from alerts ive set, Moodys is yraveling to various state capitals with forwcasts of doom due to revenue shortfalls whereever leguslatirs are in a mood to cut.
Hilarious: Chicago is issuing "AAA"-rated debt. I'm raising forecast slightly just because of how absurd this is; the ratings agencies might feel suddenly sheepish, but I'm not holding my breath.
Reaffirming my forecast for the following reasons:

Passage of time
Additional info is that Illinois' bicentennial is coming up. Some expectation of a stimulated economy will help with stability.

1 - Moody's first assign BBB3 to State of Illinois on 7/1/2017, Given 5 out of 6 months passed but rating hasn't changed. 
My 3rd try would be: 48%(first try)*1/6=8% 
2 - Holiday season: unlikely to announce big negative change on the state credit, so drop it to 2%.

If it was going to be done, my sense is that it wouldâ€™ve been done sooner. The actions of the legislature as noted in the Chicago Tribune article I think forestalled such a move, at least until the next budget battle.
Cut? Yeah maybe, it's Illinois! To Junk?! Nah!
They have not dowgraded Venezuela yet they should do it to Illions?! Dont think so.

The three agencies have all been consistently downgrading Illinois's credit rating, and the question only requires one of them to cut the credit rating down again in the next two months. The passage of the budget in July makes it unlikely the credit rating will be downgraded further however. The 3 different agencies know that downgrading Illinois so far would set an extraordinary precedent. At the beginning of the next year though, expect a re-investigation into this question due to the unresolved pension problem. Governor election incoming as well. This is all thinking past Jan 1 of course, outside the scope of the question.
Illinois is a basket case, but has kicked the can down the road for now.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Moody's first assign BBB3 to State of Illinois on 7/1/2017, Given 4 out of 6 months passed but rating hasn't changed. 
My 2nd try is: 48%(first try)*2/6=16%

Thanks to @REBurnerAccount for sharing the Fitch and S&P commentary after the recent Illinois bond sale. The bond sale (and another one later this week) should take some pressure off Illinois by lowering interest costs on the state's backlog of unpaid bills. http://www.kwqc.com/content/news/State-of-Illinois-sells-15-billion-in-bonds-451330133.html
A report released Monday says  although Illinois has the lowest credit rating in the country, the state also has a “robust economic base.”
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

1st forecast: Currently it is one level away from junk. I think the probability range for the junk ranking happing before 1/1/2018 is 10%-90%, the middle rate is 50%. Given the BBB- rating hasn't changed for  almost three months since it is first being issued, the rate change in the next 70 days will be relatively unlikely. so drop the probability to 48%

Hard to see this happening before 1 January 2018. While it is true that the state remains at risk of having its credit downgraded despite passing a budget, Fitch reaffirmed a rating that is two notches above junk (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-ratings-fitch/illinois-credit-rating-stays-investment-grade-with-fitch-idUSKBN1A22C0) and both S&P and Moody's applauded the budget decision.
Pressure on credit rating agencies to not downgrade a government entity, coupled with the recently passed budget by the Illinois state legislature, will allow the state to avoid a downgrade.
Reaffirming my forecast for the following reasons:
At moment I've no idea about.
it is not very far to 1 January but October is a dangerous time in financial markets.
Previously unknowledgeable of the situation, but a quick glance suggests it's unlikely because
No state has ever been downgraded to junk bond status yet. State Gov has usually made a concession at the last minute to avoid junk bond status.

The State's recent bond sale will help pay some of the $16B in outstanding bills.  The unfunded pension liability remains a huge concern.  It is doubtful that Moody's, Fitch, or S&P would downgrade the state's credit rating further hampering any chances of cleaning up their debt.

For a BBB- rated Local Currency state of the union, it is probable that the state of Illinois will remain at the current rating , with a sligh chance to be upgraded one notch or downgraded to Junk status.  Historical default rates based on the frequency of defaults for homogounous cohorts are avilable from the major credit rating agency S&P, Moody's and Fitch.

No state has been given junk status before. This will be the first, the ratings agencies will give its first credit rating of junk with caution. While i think it is inevitable that they will get junk status i think they will be given a chance to enact their budget. If the budget does not yield positive results they then will get the junk status rating, but not before Jan 2018.

S&P  maintains  a BBB-minus rating and stable outlook for the stateâ€™s upcoming $6 billion bond sale.  The new budget eased concerns over a liquidity crisis, but Illinois still faces fiscal challenges that could push the rating into junk.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Illinois is unable to timely pay its contractors and may already be insolvent.
Never happened before so unlikely to happen

1) Fitch have not downgraded to Junk. P(M d.|F n.d.) =10%,  P(S&P d.|F. n.d.) =10%  
2) passage of a fiscal 2018 budget, Christmas inactivity & an emotional bias against => no downgrade in the short term even if deserved
I doubt the ratings agencies will downgrade this quickly. Already move slow and could make situation worse.
I find it more likely than not.
Chicago is the largest economical city and is crime ridden.

Factoring in the fact that Illinois is largely democratic and that the Democratic party favors bail outs I don't see them tanking but with the country largely in Republican control its a very good possibility

Records from S&P, Moody's and Fitch dating back about half a century show that no states were rated junk. https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/01/reuters-america-sp-cuts-illinois-credit-rating-to-one-notch-above-junk.html

There is a chance, but very minimal, that junk status will be imposed. The reason that this is unlikely to occur is due to the progression that would ensue. Bottom line is that too much money would be lost from attached markets.

State making progress to find a solution for the problem. Several Republicans turn their back on the Gov., showing that they see the importance to save the state from 'Junk'. Despite that the credit-rating agencies won't rush a downgrading after the State started to show some progress.

Philly fed leading index just turned negative, and the state is one of few without rainy day fund.  On the other hand, Chicago is restructuring a good deal of its debt, ratings agency downgrades tend to lag bad economic news, and national economic backdrop should be stable.

I approached this problem by starting with a base probability determined by past similar situations.  Given that no state has received junk rating in the past 10 years (https://ballotpedia.org/State_credit_ratings), I would put this initial probability at 3 - 4 %, rated as highly unlikely to occur except in extraordinary circumstances.  In the case of Illinois, however, we see a trend of consistent downward ratings.  This is exacerbated by the fact that there are 3 rating agencies that each could independently decide to downgrade the state.  These combined factors might bring my 3 -4 percent up to 20 or 25 percent.
Recent passage of temporary budget relief

This is my first forecast and as an European I have no knowledge of Illinios' finances. However the top forecasters seem to be fairly confident that it is a realistic option while other are often less confident. So I will guess somewhat below the top forecasters estimates.

Republicans in the legislator have reached a tipping point. They have already taken the political damage and will continue to support tax legislation through the end of their session. A veto-proof majority is sufficient to stop the vendor payment problems, along with debt servicing. However, the structural problems in Illinois politics may have these agencies consider continuing their downgrade, keeping long term in the view. Finally, the irrational line from non-junk to junk requires greater rational lifting on the credit-agency part. Without a clear indicator to justify downgrade, status quo is likely.

If Illinois credit rating drops to junk, this will completely disrupt the municipal bond market.  It appears this has been a wake up call to the Illinois legislature to take steps to avoid junk status.  Junk status may occur, but not likely by the end of 2017.  http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-bruce-rauner-illinois-credit-rating-met-0713-20170712-story.html
it seems unlikely given Moody's just recently downgraded them, and Moody's is the most likely of the 3.  S&P has their rating outlook as stable and Fitch has them two notches above junk

Credit ratings seem to change for flaky states about once every ~4 years, there's about a third of a year left, so base rate of 8% of the credit rating changing, and 4% of it going down. It seems to have avoided dire straits recently, but it doesn't look like it's doing very well, just not as horrible as it could have been, so probably still around 4%, maybe 5% since it seems a little flakier than usual.
Their rating is already crap, they are overextended in their defined benefits, China is trying to take over the board and Chicago will ultimately implode with its corruption and malfeasance

With less than three months remaining in the year and the recent move to sell bonds to pay down debt, it seems unlikely that the credit rating will be cut by the deadline.  http://www.reuters.com/article/illinois-bonds/update-2-illinois-to-sell-6-75-bln-of-bonds-by-year-end-idUSL2N1M31YM
Trumps policies are increasing Manufacturing production YUGELY so far and the state will benefit tremendously shortly.

Moodys in their report states that the passing of the state budget creates some stability short term. On he other hand Bloomberg's quantitative credit model indicates  a high degree of distress.  This estimate has been falling, and indicates lower credit spreads than what is observed in the market.  Ratings do not change all that often, even with a negative outlook.

back in July 20, Moody says Illinois' rating won't be lowered to "junk" but warns the state still faces serious financial challenges and long-term risks. The state still has the highest unfunded pension liability in US. I suspect the real probability is higher than 60% (c75%) but we only left back 3 months till 1 January, which is why the discount. To note also if Illinois is downgraded it will be the first state in US to have a rating below investment grade.
Levels of crime and employment is a determining factor
Political gridlock remains unresolved in IL.

Illinois, has the lowest credit ratings among the 50 states, and so far it has  evaded downgrades to junk with the budget enactment. But the state's  unpaid bills topped $16 billion for the first time and the Governor Bruce Rauner said that the  sale of  $6 billion of general obligation bonds won't do not solve any problems.  A few days ago Connecticut just had its credit rating downgraded to “deep junk”, just a  few months after the city’s credit rating  was last downgraded.

I broke this assessment into 3 parts, looking at the 3 credit agencies separately. In all 3 cases, Illinois is close to the rating of junk status, and a negative change could push them over the edge. However Illinois has recently passed a budget for 2018 that makes their future outlook more positive. (http://money.cnn.com/2017/07/06/investing/illinois-budget-deal-house-override/index.html).

Although Illinois is facing insolvency and has been in such a sad state for a number of years, the passing of a budget (although it is just a "Band-Aid") is forward momentum that has not been seen over the past two years.  Now, if the question were to ask about a longer time horizon, say by the end of 2018 I would associate a greater percentage to this forecast.  Too much turbulence in the political arena in that state right now (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-budget-idUSKBN19Q2P1) but I don't think this downgrade will occur in the next three months.

Passing of budget and immediate response indicated that risk of an imminent downgrade was reduced. Long-term problems do not appear to have been addressed. Moody's appear most negative (https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-confirms-Illinois-Baa3-GO-and-related-ratings-affecting-32--PR_904132827) and suggest that issues such as pension liability could still result in a downgrade in the future, but with just three months until the deadline the chance that this happens in 2017 is still relatively low compared to pre-budget outlook.
This seems more about political gridlock than base rates.

vulnerable to sudden economic shock.
Even with large tax hike, doesn't seem able to manage debt payments, unsupported liabilities.
Still not the worst (Massachusetts) and position slightly improved in last year
First forecast, no information on the question yet. Will update after learning about the topic. Baserate of 50% seems as a reasonable starting point.

Only one state in the history of the US has declared bankruptcy, giving a base rate under 1%. Health care reform looks to be dead and budget passed which both suggest No, but structural deficit issues and Moody's history of making questionable, politically motivated ratings changes has me place the prediction somewhat higher than 1.

Actions in the state legislature seem to have reassured the ratings agencies somewhat recently. Reports are that the situation is quite serious, however.  But 1 January is only 3 months away, and the problems with the state are well known.
It's an American federal state. They'll find a way to not loose their face.

S&P, in response to the budget passing, removed the state from its credit watch for a potential downgrade.
http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-bruce-rauner-illinois-credit-rating-met-0713-20170712-story.html
It is end of the year, they will skip the decision to next year
Influencers tend to push the other direction

If one of them does, all three will do it. After confirming each rating one time, the next logical step is to downgrade Illinois, around mid December to show a strong sign. Could also be early January...
The big amount of unpaid bills makes it possible in my opinion, but according to some stereotypes I don't think any american state will  ever be standing alone.
I will try it becaus I`m intrested in.

It is more likely that the state will be assisted with some loan:
A separate bill passed by state lawmakers would allow Illinois to borrow $6 billion to help pay down some -- but not all -- of the $15 billion backlog of unpaid bills.
after 2008 no rating agency can ignore the figures

Considering the positive short term outlook (Amazon HQ2 coming?) and actions (tax hike) & a change of mind within the local government, a further downgrading appears to be rather unlikely. A downgrading may be executed, when the re-financing as planned will not be done and the pension issue remains unsolved long term.
It happend never before. There are too many chances to raise the rating again.

Planned budget for 2018 is out of balance by ~1 billion, it may will not reach "junk" status in 2018 but most likely by 2020 http://www.politifact.com/illinois/statements/2017/sep/20/bruce-rauner/rauners-right-illinois-budget-balancing-act-ongoin/

The status has just been lowered this year and never has been a state at junk status before. Doing so would be a severe and representative action which will not occur in such short-time as the last "warning" has just been given.

The budget might be stable for now, the overall financial situation is slightly positve and as on of the biggest parts of the US economic markets, there is the concideration of the agencys to not label the State of Illinois as junk for other states might get sucked into a downpath overall.
Down or up rates are always economic influenced decissions. Illinois is a high ranked producer of soy, corn and ethanol in the US. A downrate will stop big companies invest money.
Too Little time for them to react.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Dropping to zero because the state passed a successful budget.
The ratings agencies wouldn't dare. Not this year.
I see this coming more into Febuary 2018.

The rating agenceis were looking for a budget and received it. However, it was passed using a veto override vote, which is not quite what they were looking for (on July 5th Moody's warned that they could still downgrade even with a budget).

As long as enough Illinois Republicans continue to support the innovative strategy called "pay the bills"; they should be OK.

Both S&P and Moody’s have backed off their warnings about lowering Illinois' rating to junk.  (See here http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-moodys-illinois-credit-rating-20170720-story.html).  This should influence Fitch to stay on the sidelines also.  Over the next three months, I expect the probabilities to decay to close to zero.  There should be warnings first from S&P or Moody’s before any credit re-rating.

To start with the big picture, no state has ever been downgraded to junk status. With that in mind, below are links about two of the three deciding not to downgrade the state. Moody's has yet to weigh in but given the new budget I think the risk has substantially receded.

Moodys has Baa3 (1 away from junk) outlook "neg"
S&P has BBB- (1 away from junk) outlook "stable"
Fitch has BBB (2 away from junk) outlook "neg"
It only takes one to make this happen and Illinois has a recent history of consistently declining credit ratings.

WIth the new budget and a plethora of new taxes Illinois should continue to avoid the junk bond rating at least until after the governors election.   It takes time for a one time power house state like Illinois to completely fall apart.  It continues to march in that direction by postponing the painful reality of having promises made which can not be met.  What will be interesting is which of the government responsibilities not met will be the one to finally cause the house of cards to collapse,
Health, education infrastructure or safety?
Illinois narrowly avoided becoming the first U.S. state ever slapped with a "junk" credit rating from S&P Global Ratings after it passed its first budget in more than two years.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Recent budget saves the day until next year (only just). With new revenue no risk of missing bond payment due to competing court-mandated payments to other creditors.

As I have previously mentioned, I believe S&P will be the first to announce Illinois in the junk credit rating.  Moody’s just lowered them in June and probably won’t lower them again within 6 months.  Fitch seemingly is not going to lead since it is the smallest credit rating agency.

my cynical view says Illinois is so corrupt that I am betting on them doing anything to avoid this, time frame is short and there will be enormous pressure on agencies to avoid this downgrade. But I hope it happens, on a personal level.

The freshly adopted budget isn't fooling anyone, least of all the rating agencies:  It will not do anything to improve the state's financial position, even in the short term.   Nobody wants to be in office around election time when your bonds have become junk--not only do your borrowing costs go up instantly and dramatically, but there is a major sell-off of existing debt by agencies and entities who are not allowed to hold junk as part of a capital requirement; this includes, for example, all the public retirement systems in Illinois and I imagine a fair number of banks.  And while most voters don't bother to understand this, they almost always get the idea that it's pretty embarrassing--and if you're an incumbent, it's at least partly your fault.
Since I can't see an obvious way to reply to the comments on my forecast, I'll do it here.  Pardon my ignorance.  Maybe I should try Chrome.

Illinois has suffered numerous downgrades from various S&P, Moody's and Fitch since 2009.  The last ratings change from Moody's for Illinois was June 1, 2017.  Currently, S&P, Moody's and Fitch rates Illinois one step above junk status.
